Award.AwardTitle: A Hybrid Course Model of Peer-Led Learning for the Social Sciences

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
This project is advancing undergraduate STEM education through the expansion of the well-established Peer-Led Team Learning (PLTL) model, which has proven to be successful in the natural sciences, into courses in the social sciences. The work is being conducted at Northeastern Illinois University (NEIU), a Hispanic Serving Institution (HSI) with a highly diverse student body, in which 56% of the students are minorities and roughly 60% of incoming freshmen are first-generation college students. NEIU is a commuter school with a sizeable number of non-traditional students who work full- or part-time, and have difficulty getting to campus outside of regular class periods.

The psychology department is one of the largest departments on campus and is challenged to meet the needs of the numerous students and the diverse body of majors and minors in the department. Within the psychology courses and major, some of the most acute challenges include retaining minority students, creating common learning spaces and communities, and making course support accessible to all students. This project is evolving a modified PLTL model that relies on online technology to address the departmental challenges. Further, this project is allowing the faculty to determine whether the modified PLTL model is successful in expanding access for the many non-traditional students that comprise the NEIU student body. The project builds upon an existing Peer Mentor program in the STEM fields and now piloted in psychology. Ultimately, the work will add in-person and online PLTL-style workshops to three entry-level psychology courses and inject the careful use of technology to augment access, communication, and learning groups. In addition to enhancing access, the project team expects the small-group, peer led interactions - both in-person and online - to improve student retention via the development of collaborative learning communities.

Project proposal objectives are to:
- design, implement and disseminate a modified PLTL model that is tailored for psychology courses and may be easily adapted for other social sciences;
- design Peer led workshops that can be delivered online in order to increase access for non-traditional students;
- investigate and evaluate the success of online Peer led interactions and small group activities; and
- evaluate the program's effectiveness for improving student performance, retention and increasing participation of non-traditional students.

This project has potential interest for social science departments that would like to draw upon the success of the PLTL model and for institutions serving non-traditional students.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Peer-led learning techniques have been found to promote active learning and student success. One such strategy is the Peer-Led Team Learning (PLTL) Model. This model provides weekly student-led workshops in addition to regularly held lectures. The workshop provides learning opportunities by creating a comfortable environment where students can actively interact with the content knowledge covered in the course. In workshops, peer leaders assist as students work together to solve preset problems, the aims of which are to encourage critical thinking and apply concepts to novel contexts and problems.  In order to achieve the maximum benefit of PLTL, peer-led groups should be approximately five to eight students in size. One element that sets PLTL apart from other collaborative learning models is the development of the peer leaders themselves. Thus, this model enhances learning at two levels: that of the student, and at the more advanced level of the peer leader. Though application of PLTL is growing in STEM fields, few social science disciplines have adopted it. This project represents our implementation of PLTL into our entry-level psychology courses.

Intellectual Merit

Our General Psychology course (PSYC 200) and our Statistics and Research Methods sequence (PSYC 202 and 302) have proven difficult for a large proportion of our psychology majors and minors, with many earning poor grades or withdrawing from classes. Thus in addition to extending PLTL to psychology, we implemented it in the hopes of boosting student performance, improving retention, and assisting minority students. Finally, PLTL enabled students on our commuter campus to find learning communities and develop connections with classmates.

Historically, PSYC 200 was a test-based course (i.e., Mastery learning). It was difficult for students because they received no lectures and studied independently gain mastery by passing unit quizzes. In this format, PSYC 200 had a high withdraw and low pass rate. Our TUES grant enabled us to transform PSYC 200 to a course in which students met twice per week, once for faculty-led lectures and the second for PLTL workshops. Mastery testing that was the focus of class sessions was moved online. With PLTL, students learned material at a deeper level, improved their critical thinking skills, and improved in their course grade.

We also tested a procedure to instill a growth mindset (intelligence as fluid and malleable) in our students. We prompted students to adopt the belief that that effort and “exercise” would lead to brain growth, expecting that this would instill greater resilience in tackling intellectually challenging and difficult material. Indeed, PSYC 200 students who received this mindset intervention were less likely to withdraw from the course. Withdraw rates dropped from 29% pre-PLTL to 14% with PLTL and brief interventions.

Our Statistics and Research Methods sequence has always included student aids as tutors. These were students who had recently taken the course and done well. Their job was mainly to hold out-of-class office hours. As a result of TUES funding we transformed this model into the more substantial Peer Leader program. This included the addition of both in-class and out-of-class peer-led workshops, and longstanding groups were established to produce comfortable learning communities. In order to increase access, we added asynchronous online discussion groups (via Desire2Learn) and synchronous online PLTL groups via Adobe Connect. Both the types of activities improved students’ learning experience and connection to a larger learning community.

As a result of changes to these courses, we saw significant increases in students’ research and methodology understanding, improved familiarity with APA style, and increases in critical thinking. Further, improvement in student grades, coupled with high student satisfaction levels, suggests overwhelmingly that PLTL has had a positive impact on student learning and performance!

Overall we view our implementation of PLTL to be a success. Our students benefitted, our peer leaders developed, and we were also enriched. We have learned a lot about the model, and our experiences have deepened our own knowledge of student learning, motivation, and success.

Broader Impact

The research that we have conducted has supported the adoption of PLTL models as a practice in the social and behavioral sciences.  We have generated significant support for the overall utility of PLTL outside of the natural sciences.

As schools struggle with maintaining and increasing student enrollment, while students seek alternate paths to learning, we offer PLTL as a solution these converging problems.  If we are able to provide ways for higher learning institutions to encourage learning communities among the student body while also offering students a more flexible, responsive, and developmentally-attentive method of learning, we will be able to increase both access to and the effectiveness of higher education.  This substantive change in the ways we as educators approach our students has the potential to yield great outcomes in the lives of many who are seeking to improve themselves and their standing.
